title: Are there any herbs that are also properly considered spices? - Quora

response.answer_text: Herbs come from the leafy and green part of the plant. Spices are parts of the plant other than the leafy bit such as the root, stem, bulb, bark or seeds. Examples of herbs include basil, oregano, thyme, rosemary, parsley and mint. Spices are usually dried before being used to season foods. Some examples are cinnamon, cloves, ginger and pepper. Unlike herbs, they are grown in more tropical countries. They’ve also been known to preserve foods and some have medicinal value, such as turmeric with its anti-inflammatory, anti-fungal properties. Despite the above clarification, according to the American Spice Trade Association spices are defined as “any dried plant product used primarily for seasoning purposes”. This really broadens the definition of spices, allowing it to include herbs, dehydrated veggies, spice blends and spice seeds.

response.answer_text: Leaves, flowers and stems are supposed to be considered herbs, while fruits, seeds, barks, roots and other parts of the plants are supposed to be considered spices. There is no scientific reason behind this. It’s just a convention and a very loose one at that. Saffron is considered a spice. We use its flowers. Dried jujube is considered a herb. We use its fruits. I don’t think this is a topic worth wasting time thinking about.

This is really a social construction rather than science, rather the way we assign ‘vegetables’ or fruits. Fruits ARE a technical description - the seed bearing body, e.g. tomato - but we often call fruits vegetables. Herbs are supposed to be the leaves and stems, but most of us casually refer to the whole kit and caboodle as ‘spices.’ I wouldn’t spend a lot of time over thinking this. A lot of us add salt - a mineral - the category of spices.

response.answer_text: Well, herbs are leaves and spices are other parts. Nobody eats the root bulb of thyme, nor the leaves of nutmeg. Salt is neither, it’s just a mineral. But with coriander (seed) and cilantro (leaf) there are some plants we use both parts of. Dill. Fennel. In fact, when roasting a chicken, I like shoving fennel fronds up its wazoo, and slicing the fennel bulb up with the carrots and onions and potatoes in the roasting pan. But I would say cilantro/coriander is the closest to completely conflating herb and spice.

Their are Two that have both. cilantro and coriander that are considered to be a herb and a spice.

response.answer_text: Herbs are green, leafy plants. Spices are seeds, nuts, husks, roots, etc. Spices should go in the beginning because most will mix nicely with fat and don't lose all their flavor. Herbs on the other hand, are more delicate and should go at the end. The exception is dried herbs which can also go in at the beginning.
